sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on The Monroe Doctrine. American Foreign Policy (1823). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Clara, age 15, daughter of a State Department clerk, 1823.

I'm Clara, fifteen, and my father works at the State Department in Washington. Today President Monroe announced a new foreign policy that will shape America's future: the Monroe Doctrine. The situation is this: Spain's colonies in Latin America have been fighting for independence, inspired by our revolution. Spain wants to reconquer them with help from European powers.
visuals: Chapter title: Europe and the Americas
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Clara, fifteen, and my father works at the State Department in Washington.

sections.narration: The Monroe Doctrine shows how much America has changed since 1776. We've survived two wars with Britain. We've doubled our size. We're growing economically.
sections.key_takeaway: The Monroe Doctrine shows how much America has changed since 1776.

sections.narration: Father explains why the doctrine was necessary. After Napoleon's defeat, European monarchies formed the Holy Alliance—Russia, Prussia, Austria, and later France. They were committed to crushing republican and democratic movements, restoring monarchy and "legitimate" rule wherever revolutions occurred. The Holy Alliance helped Spain suppress rebellions in Europe.
visuals: Chapter title: The Holy Alliance Threat
sections.key_takeaway: Father explains why the doctrine was necessary.

sections.narration: I've learned about the revolutions sweeping Latin America. Leaders like Simón Bolívar in South America and Miguel Hidalgo in Mexico led wars for independence, inspired by America's example. They wrote constitutions modeled on ours, established republics, abolished many (though not all) aspects of colonial society. These new nations looked to America for support.
sections.key_takeaway: I've learned about the revolutions sweeping Latin America.

sections.narration: The Monroe Doctrine reveals American ambitions. We're not just protecting other nations' independence—we're claiming the Western Hemisphere as our sphere of influence. We're warning Europe that we'll be the dominant power here, that our interests matter most in the Americas. This will shape American foreign policy for centuries.
sections.key_takeaway: The Monroe Doctrine reveals American ambitions.

sections.narration: The Monroe Doctrine marks America's transition from struggling republic to confident power. Just forty years after our founding, we're declaring ourselves protector of an entire hemisphere. We're telling European empires—Britain, France, Spain, Russia—to stay out of Western Hemisphere affairs. This confidence comes from surviving and thriving.
visuals: Chapter title: A New American Role
sections.key_takeaway: The Monroe Doctrine marks America's transition from struggling republic to confident power.

sections.narration: In this lesson, we explored The Monroe Doctrine through 6 chapters. Key concepts included: Monroe Doctrine, James Monroe, John Quincy Adams, Sphere of Influence.
